kszucs commented on a change in pull request #2385: ARROW-3002: Inconsistent DataType Hashing
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2385#discussion_r208031331
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/types.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -420,7 +420,7 @@ cdef class Field:
         return self.__str__()
 
     def __hash__(self):
-        return hash((self.field.name(), self.type.id))
+        return hash((self.field.name(), self.type, self.field.nullable()))
 
 Review comment:
   I guess We should hash the metadata too. 
   The hashing could be factored out, it's equivalent with
   
   ```py
   hash(self.__reduce__()[1])
   ```
   
   

----------------------------------------------------------------

kszucs commented on a change in pull request #2385: ARROW-3002: Inconsistent DataType Hashing
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2385#discussion_r208031331
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/types.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -420,7 +420,7 @@ cdef class Field:
         return self.__str__()
 
     def __hash__(self):
-        return hash((self.field.name(), self.type.id))
+        return hash((self.field.name(), self.type, self.field.nullable()))
 
 Review comment:
   I guess We should hash the metadata too. Can someone confirm it?
   
   The hashing could be factored out, it's equivalent with
   
   ```py
   hash(self.__reduce__()[1])
   ```
   
   But cython probably compiles it away if We reference the fields explicitly. Which one is preferred?

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #2385: ARROW-3002: [Python] Hash more parts of pyarrow.Field
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2385#discussion_r208264741
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/types.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -420,7 +420,7 @@ cdef class Field:
         return self.__str__()
 
     def __hash__(self):
-        return hash((self.field.name(), self.type.id))
+        return hash((self.field.name(), self.type, self.field.nullable()))
 
 Review comment:
   IMO the current form is preferred. The `__reduce__` variant is cryptic.
   And no, I don't think we should hash the metadata. A hash function should be fast while minimizing _real-world_ collisions.

               pa.field('b', pa.string())], mode=pa.lib.UnionMode_SPARSE),

wesm commented on issue #2385: ARROW-3002: [Python] Hash more parts of pyarrow.Field
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2385#issuecomment-411206222
 
 
   I personally don't care for `pytest.parametrize`. Among other things, it can give a false sense of a test suite being much larger than it is (I've commented to @cpcloud about this several times). It's also a bit of a bummer that parametrize does not support fixtures as arguments

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

cpcloud commented on issue #2385: ARROW-3002: [Python] Hash more parts of pyarrow.Field
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2385#issuecomment-411210646
 
 
   I like parametrize.
   
   The body of a test IMO should contain the "kernel" of what's being tested and a loop that's iterating over a bunch test cases is not part of that kernel. I also want to be able to specify what specific value of a parameter I can test.
   
   parametrize was pretty useful in writing [a set of tests for ibis](https://github.com/ibis-project/ibis/tree/master/ibis/tests/all) that run a subset of tests for across each backend.
   
   i would've wasted a lot of time and the code would've been less readable IMO if i had to write the loops by hand, and in fact i would've just been rewriting machinery that already existed.
   
   I see no reason not to make use of tool because someone else is able to convince themselves that they are being more productive by seeing more dots on a screen. The merit of a tool shouldn't be based on how others misuse it.
   
   As far as passing fixtures to parametrize goes, I think that probably just needs a bit of old-fashioned open source TLC: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/349.

----------------------------------------------------------------

fields.description:
{code:python}
>>> x = pa.field('record', pa.struct([pa.field('x', pa.int32(), nullable=False)]))
>>> y = pa.field('record', pa.struct([pa.field('x', pa.int32(), nullable=True)]))
>>> z = pa.field('record', pa.struct([pa.field('x', pa.int32(), nullable=True)]))
>>> x.__hash__()
-9223372036569171727
>>> y.__hash__()
285604054
>>> z.__hash__()
285604076
>>> x.type
StructType(struct<x: int32>)
>>> x.type.__hash__()
429437081997812647
>>> y.type.__hash__()
429437081997812647
>>> x
pyarrow.Field<record: struct<x: int32>>
>>> y
pyarrow.Field<record: struct<x: int32>>

{code}

Expected: 

y.__hash__() should be the same as z.__hash__()

x.type.__hash__() should be different than y.type.__hash__()

comments.body: That's not really a bug. A hash function doesn't have to be injective. However, feel free to post a PR if you feel that improvement is worth it.
Well, technically it is not a bug. Hash functions are allowed to have collisions. It would be better for this not to generate a collision though
Fair! it just caught me off guard is all :) You can delete this if it isn't useful in other locations, I have a workaround for what I was trying to accomplish that is pretty light weight.
